pageContext.title: Richard Sackville, 3rd Earl of Dorset (1589-1624)
pageContext.description_physical:
Colour losses are evident around the top border, evident in the raking light and NIR images. Possible losses or retouchings are documented by UV in the flesh tones, which appear bright white and likely due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath. The orange UV fluorescence documented in portions of the flesh tones and the lace on the collar is due to the use of lead white.
The x-ray image shows the distribution of heavy elements, such as lead, in the background and on the white lace, whereas the flesh tones seem to contain only a small amount of lead-based pigments.
pageContext.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, lead white; red lace: vermilion; orange slashes: red lead; white collar: lead white, carbon black (for shading)
pageContext.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Skin: lead white, lead tin yellow, red lead(?); lips: red lead(?)
pageContext.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead tin yellow, lead white, red lead(?), carbon-based black

references_id.display_title: Catalogue of the Historical Collection of Miniatures formed by Mr. J. Lumsden Propert - Exhibition No. 164
